body: Outside George and Patricia Smyth’s home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, the street was awash with floating debris. Among the more notable items that Hurricane Sandy had flushed from their flooded basement were hundreds of ice cream cones and jars full of toppings, inventory from the business they were forced to close last year.
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Losses Mount For a Family Struggling To Keep Afloat

body:
New York City, still reeling from the impact of Hurricane Sandy , will expand its evacuation zones, tighten building codes and look for ways to fortify critical infrastructure like transportation and electrical networks from future natural disasters, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday.
 
But while the mayor said he would aggressively
title: Mayor Pledges to Rebuild and Fortify Coast

body: Like other parks in and around the Rockaways, Floyd Bennett Field has accepted the rubble of collapsed communities, becoming more landfill than green space in the weeks after Hurricane Sandy laid waste to the peninsula. On the former runways sit mounds of fallen trees, branches and wood chips from tree debris — almost 100,000 cubic yards in
title: New York City’s Plan for Tree Waste: Sell, Reuse or Burn

body:
It was the little things, the sudden absence of everyday fixtures, that disoriented residents in the Rockaways in the days after the storm, as much as the loss of house and home. The traffic lights had gone dark. Where was one to get a prescription filled? And oh, what about books due at the library?
 
The Rockaways still look like ghost
title: Despite Ruin, Library Offers Books and Community

body:
As with so many others living on the storm-battered coast, Audrey Shields did not know almost until the last minute whether Thanksgiving would be celebrated at her home this year, as it had nearly every fourth Thursday of November for a half-century. 
 
Ms. Shields, who is 79 and uses a wheelchair, had not left her 14th-floor apartment in
title: Day to Reflect After Bearing Storm’s Wrath

title: Day to Reflect After Bearing Storm’s Wrath

body:
In the low-lying neighborhoods of New York City where Hurricane Sandy flooded so many basements, leaving their occupants stuck in the cold and the dark, Louis Santo, a licensed electrician, has become an extraordinarily popular man.
 
As soon as Hurricane Sandy swirled away from the city, homeowners and landlords started calling Mr. Santo
title: Demand for Electricians Soars After Hurricane

body:
New York City is moving to demolish hundreds of homes in the neighborhoods hit hardest by Hurricane Sandy , after a grim assessment of the storm-ravaged coast revealed that many structures were so damaged they pose a danger to public safety and other buildings nearby.
 
About 200 homes will be bulldozed in the coming weeks and months,
title: After the Storm, City Bulldozers

body:
If any neighborhood could have been expected to cope smoothly with Hurricane Sandy , it should have been Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, which is rich with police officers, firefighters and emergency medics accustomed to dealing with other people’s disasters.
 
Yet, more than a week later, Gerritsen Beach is worse off than all but a few
title: Neighborhood That Emergency Workers Call Home Is Still Reeling From Storm

body:
A northeaster threatened to unravel progress made since Hurricane Sandy ravaged the New York area, delivering a second angry serving of howling wind and high water on Wednesday in places where misery and frustration had yet to recede.
 
The northeaster, a chilly brew of rain and wet snow blown in by gusts almost as powerful as those
title: Northeaster Adds to the Misery, Dumping Rain and Wet Snow

body:
ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has dismissed his chief of emergency management after learning that he deployed government workers to clear a tree at his Long Island home during Hurricane Sandy , an administration official said Wednesday.
 
The aide, Steven Kuhr, was the director of the State Office of Emergency Management . The office
title: Cuomo Fires Emergency Office Chief for Misusing Workers in Hurricane

body:
Watching the Manhattan skyline shimmer over Jamaica Bay had always been one of the charms of life in the Rockaways. But now, when the Empire State Building winks on each night, those lights feel almost like a punch in the gut.
 
It felt that way to the two women caked in the sandy silt that still blankets most streets here, as they trudged
title: In Sight of Manhattan Skyline, Living Forlorn and in the Dark

author: Dan Klores is a Peabody Award-winning filmmaker and playwright. His first film was ''The Boys of Second Street Park.''
body: Before I was to play in the public school gym or the local Y, and at about the same time I had my first crush on Annette, the Mouseketeer , I used to gaze at the tall, gray steel backboard with the orange rim. For my first shot, I used a dodgeball. I didn't have, let alone own, a real ball, a Voit. My sporting life in Brooklyn had actually begun
title: ESSAY; The Brooklyn Game Had Its Own Beat

body: ON a recent Sunday, as a guitar player did his best Tom Petty imitation, a pirate politely enjoyed brunch on the deck of the Wharf Bar and Restaurant, overlooking Jamaica Bay. In a knit cap with rhinestone skull and crossbones, a jacket with golden epaulets and a scruffy and ashen beard, he hoisted his Budweiser in a toast: ''To the captain!'' The
title: Where Pirates Can Dock and Dine in New York

body: GEORGE R. BROADHEAD, a retired newspaper executive and Marine Corps veteran, has lived in Beverly Hills and Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Greenwich, Conn., among many other places. The place he is choosing to spend his retirement, though, is the place where he grew up: Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn .That doesn't mean Mr. Broadhead, who is the president
title: LIVING IN | GERRITSEN BEACH, BROOKLYN; The Art of Hiding in Plain Sight

body: For much of the past century, Brooklyn was the Rodney Dangerfield of boroughs, known for its blue-collar style, for its funny accent and, of course, for getting no respect. Then came the brownstone homesteaders and the bohemian pioneers. They turned lunch-bucket warrens in Park Slope, Dumbo and Williamsburg into glamorous destinations, drawing a
title: As Brooklyn Gentrifies, Some Neighborhoods Are Being Left Behind

body: The voice wafts above the traffic, its cadences prodding but familiar, offering directions to a city that does not like to ask for them. It is not a computer, listeners notice. It is certainly not an actor. A Dutch couple visiting for the week was able to narrow its origins to ''American'' and, eventually, ''not Texas.'' But to the initiated ear,
title: A Voice of New York's Streets, Saying That It's Safe to Wawk

body: A construction worker died on Tuesday in Brooklyn when part of a house collapsed, the authorities said. The man, Santos Garcia, 25, of the Borough Park section, was pronounced dead at Lutheran Medical Center, the police said. Mr. Garcia and five colleagues were converting a one-story bungalow-like building into a two-story home at 40 Frank Court in
title: CITY ROOM; Worker Dies When Portion Of a House Collapses
